title: Electron Inertia and Magnetic Reconnection
abstract: The finite electron mass can cause magnetic reconnection even in the absence of any other non-ideal effect. It will be shown that when electron inertia is the only non-ideal effect in the evolution of a magnetic field $\vec{B}$, there is a related field that evolves ideally. This field is $\vec{\mathcal{B}} \equiv \vec{B} + \vec{\nabla}\times \left( (c/\omega_{pe})^2\mu_0\vec{j} \right)$ with $\omega_{pe}$ the plasma frequency and $\vec{j}$ the current density. In three dimensional space, the practical importance of the ideal evolution of $\vec{\mathcal{B}}$ on its reconnection appears limited. When the evolution velocity of modified field is chaotic, $\vec{\mathcal{B}}$ will reconnect on a timescale that depends only logarithmically on any non-ideal effect that is diffusive, such as resistivity, with a current density enhancement that is also proportional to the logarithm. In near ideal magnetic fields, this logarithm is typically of order ten, and it is difficult to conceive of a physically realistic situation in which it larger than a hundred.
